intro: Erythrodes triantherae var. ecalcarata, commonly known as the scarlet sandalwood, is a rare and striking plant native to the tropical regions of Southeast Asia. It is characterized by its vibrant red flowers, which are highly ornamental and attract a variety of pollinators. The plant typically grows in shaded, humid environments, often in forest understories where it can receive adequate moisture. Its leaves are lance-shaped and have a smooth texture, while its stems are woody and can reach moderate heights. Due to its rarity and unique appearance, it is often cultivated in botanical gardens and specialized collections.
